abstract.text: A customizable item picker control for the Touch Bar.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: On supported MacBook Pro models, you can use a scrubber (an instance of the

class) to provide a horizontally-oriented, item-picker control in the Touch Bar. Use a scrubber to let the user pick an item from a related collection, such as a photo from a library or a date from a date range.
Refer to the following sample code projects which demonstrate how to use
and related classes, including the
class:
Each item that appears in a scrubber is a specialized view that supports selection and scrubber-appropriate decorations. The scrubber keeps track of its items by their index positions.
Take care to understand the Touch Bar term
items
. An item for a scrubber
is
a view — an
instance — at a specific index position in the scrubber. This is analogous to a row in a table. An item for a bar (an instance of the
class), by contrast, is an
instance, which
has
a view.

There are many classes in the scrubber API, as well as a delegate protocol, a data source protocol, and a callback-based layout API. The design pattern is reminiscent of that used for a collection view (an instance of the
class). You might find it helpful to refer to the
overview for background. Be aware, though of the differences. For example, while scrubbers and collection views both employ a
method, and both employ a reuse queue, a scrubber is subclassed from the
class while a collection view is subclassed from the
class.
A scrubber employs:
The
scrubber object
itself (an instance of the
class), which serves as a container view that shows a subview for each scrubber item, and which employs a reuse-queue pattern for efficiency and performance.
A
data source
(conforming to the
protocol), which provides scrubber items to the scrubber, on demand, from an associated data collection in your app. Specify the data source in the scrubber’s
property
A
delegate
(conforming to the
protocol), which responds to user interaction — such as with its
and
methods. Specify the delegate in the scrubber’s
property. You can also use the delegate to respond to the highlighting and selection of scrubber items, and to respond to changes in which items are visible in the scrubber.
A
layout
(an instance of a subclass of the
abstract class, typically the

concrete subclass). You implement a layout to respond to calls, from the system, to return view specifications for the items to be displayed in the scrubber. The layout, in this way, assists in arranging and decorating the scrubber’s contained items, and in providing appearance changes in response to user interaction. Specify the layout in the scrubber’s
property.
Before learning how to use a scrubber in the Touch Bar, be sure you read the overview for the
class.
A scrubber employs a data source and a delegate, using a pattern similar to that used for collection views, as follows:
Data source.
To supply items for a scrubber, implement an object that conforms to the
protocol and specify that object in the scrubber’s
property. There are two built-in item types, provided by the
and
concrete classes. For more on scrubber items, see
The following code shows an example implementation of the
datasource method, returning the count of items displayed by the scrubber.
In addition to the count of scrubber items, you use the datasource method to provide individual items with the
method. An example implementation is shown in the following code.

code: func scrubber(_ scrubber: NSScrubber, viewForItemAt index: Int) -> NSScrubberItemView {    let itemView = scrubber.makeItem(withIdentifier: "TextScrubberItemIdentifier", owner: self) as! NSScrubberTextItemView

inlineContent.text: To optimize resource usage and performance, a scrubber employs a reuse queue that’s similar to the reuse queue for an
object.
Delegate.
To respond to user interactions and to visibility, highlighting, and selection changes, implement a delegate object that conforms to the
protocol and specify that object in the scrubber’s
property.
The following code shows a minimal implementation of the
delegate method for a scrubber.

code: func scrubber(_ scrubber: NSScrubber, didSelectItemAt index: Int) {
// Log the index value for the item the user selected
// Log the index value for the item the user selected    NSLog(@"selectedIndex = %ld", selectedIndex);

inlineContent.text: A scrubber offers many built-in permutations for touch interaction. By subclassing a scrubber, you can customize touch interaction.
To specify a scrubber’s touch-interaction model, set values for the following, cooperating scrubber properties:
, and
. Here’s how to choose the right permutation of values for these properties:
Scrolling or fixed.
Decide whether you want the scrubber to
scroll
to track horizontal finger movement across the scrubber, or to remain
fixed
in place as the finger moves.
For scrolling, specify the
value for the scrubber’s
property.
For a fixed scrubber, specify the
value for the

property (this is the default value). In this case, if the user’s finger reaches the left or right edge of the scrubber view and there are items beyond the edge, the scrubber automatically scrolls to bring those items into view.
Selection style.
Decide whether you want item selection to take place only upon a deliberate selection gesture, or continuously during horizontal finger movement on the scrubber.
For deliberate selection, specify a value of
for the scrubber’s
property (this is the default value). In
free
(scrolling) mode, the user must then tap an item to highlight and select it. In
fixed

(non-scrolling) mode, ending interaction with the scrubber, by lifting the finger, selects the most-recently highlighted item. However, if there is already a highlighted item before interaction starts, and the user resumes interacting with the (fixed mode) scrubber on that item, selection changes continuously, tracking the user’s finger — even though the
property value is
For continuous selection, specify a value of
for the
property. Item selection behavior then depends on the
and
property values, as described in
Item alignment.
The setting in the scrubber’s
property affects two things: 1) item highlighting and selection, and 2) the resting position of scrubber items after manual or automatic scrolling. Available values for this property are
, and
. See the
enumeration for details on how these constants work.
Your choices for scrolling, selection, and alignment jointly impact highlighting and selection behavior. For details on highlighting and selection, see
. Your choice for alignment also impacts scrubber-item resting-position behavior following a scroll interaction. For details on resting position, see
In free mode with continuous selection style (the
property value is
and the
property value is
for this configuration), the scrubber item on the alignment axis is automatically highlighted and selected. The
alignment axis
is the left edge, right edge, or center of the scrubber, as you specify by setting the value of the
property using constants from the
enumeration. Specifying an alignment axis of
is equivalent to a value of
for position-based item selection.
In free mode with deliberate selection style (the
property value is
and the
property value is
for this configuration), the system ignores the
property value in terms of item selection.
In fixed mode (the
property value is
for this configuration), the system ignores the
property value in terms of item selection — no matter which value you specify for the
property.
The value you provide in the
property specifies the automatic scrubber item resting position that follows manual or automatic scrolling. (This value also affects item highlighting and selection, as described in
.) The system respects your setting for resting position irrespective of the values of the
and
properties.
Specifically:

— In a left-to-right language, the scrubber comes to rest, following manual or automatic scrolling, so that the left edge of the leftmost scrubber item is coincident with the left edge of the scrubber.
— The scrubber comes to rest, following manual or automatic scrolling, so that a scrubber item is perfectly centered in the scrubber.

— In a left-to-right language, the scrubber comes to rest, following manual or automatic scrolling, so that the right edge of the rightmost scrubber item is coincident with the right edge of the scrubber.
— Following manual or automatic scrolling, the scrubber comes to rest without attempting to align any scrubber item.
A scrubber configures the views for its items with the help of two classes,
and
, as described in this section.
A
layout
is a concrete implementation of the
abstract class. AppKit provides two concrete, preconfigured layout subclasses:
and
. If you use one of these built-in layout types, there’s no additional layout code to write, apart from adding your choice of built-in layout to the scrubber’s
property. This Swift example shows this simple step for the flow layout:
To create a custom layout, subclass the
class and implement its callback methods. Unlike a view delegate (such as used for a table view), which provides
views
on demand, scrubber layout callbacks provide
view specifications
on demand. Using these callbacks, you specify:
Scrubber item geometry
Scrubber item appearance
Layout life cycle for state management
Specify the overall visual dimensions of a custom scrubber when you create it, using the
or
initializer, or by using Interface Builder.
Return the total width and height for the elements in a custom scrubber, including those not currently visible, using the
property in your layout. Specify height and width in points. To use the standard height, specify a value of
Specify the geometry and appearance for items in your custom scrubber, using the two required callback methods that each return instances of the
class. The system calls one or another of these methods, as it needs to, as a user interacts with a layout’s owning scrubber:
Callback method
How to use
Return
one
instance that specifies the view attribute values for the one scrubber item at the index position requested by the system in the method call.
Return the
set of

instances that, together, specify the per-item view attributes for the items within the visible rectangle requested by the system in the method call. The set you return must contain one layout attributes object for each item in the rectangle.
You can explicitly invalidate a layout by calling the
method. Do this whenever your app changes a scrubber’s information in a way that requires a layout update. For example, if you change the text shown in one or more items, invalidate the layout.

You can specify layout life cycle in terms of the conditions under which a layout should be automatically invalidated, such as when the user selects something different in the layout’s owning scrubber. The API for automatic invalidation consists of the following two properties and one method:
For example, if you design a scrubber’s layout characteristics to depend on which of its items is selected by the user, return a value of
from the scrubber’s
method.A
layout attributes
object is an instance of the
class, which you configure to describe the view for a single item. The class offers the following built-in attributes for you to work with:
— The item’s index position within the scrubber
— The item’s frame rectangle
— The item’s transparency
You can specify additional item attributes by subclassing the
class. For example, you could specify a geometric transform attribute.
If you’re using a custom
subclass, provide an implementation for the
method to clear any custom layout state, such as by discarding cached data.
The flip side of layout invalidation (as described in
) is preparation for redrawing, which you perform in a layout’s
method. The goal of layout preparation is to optimize performance. A scrubber calls the
method exactly once between invalidation and redrawing. Complete as much one-time, up-front layout work as you can, in advance of redrawing, in this step. For example, your
implementation should perform initial layout calculations and should fill caches needed during drawing.
After the
method returns, the system updates the scrubber view hierarchy with repeated calls to three
methods:
, and
. Implement these methods to provide return values as quickly as possible, taking advantage of the work you did during layout preparation.
The view that represents a scrubber item is provided by your data source object, using the
protocol method. AppKit provides two purpose-built view classes you can use, both of which are concrete subclasses of the abstract
class:
has
, and
properties
has
and
properties
To create a custom item, subclass these or their abstract superclass,
To show a scrubber, associate it with an

object (adding it, as the view for a custom item or popover item, to the bar) and then associate the bar with the appropriate responder object in your app. The system then shows the scrubber in the Touch Bar only at appropriate times. For more information on bars and the responder chain, read the overview for the
class.

content.text: Choose between a scrubber and a scroll view

inlineContent.text: When choosing between a scrubber and a scroll view, use a scrubber unless the amount of content, or the nature of your content, doesn’t work well in a scrubber. Scrubber interaction is optimized for the Touch Bar, typically making a scrubber the better option for letting the user pick from among several choices, such as dates in a calendar.

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your macOS app.
A role-based protocol that declares the minimum interface necessary to interact with an assistive app.
The complete list of properties and methods for accessible elements.
A set of methods that defines a way to add animation to an existing class with a minimum of API impact.
A set of methods for getting and setting the appearance attributes of a view.
An ordered collection of data items displayed in a customizable layout.
A set of methods that the destination object (or recipient) of a dragged image must implement.
A customizable item picker control for the Touch Bar.
The specified preferred alignment of items within the scrubber, when they come to rest following a user’s scrolling or paging interaction.
Center alignment of items within the scrubber.
Leading alignment of items within the scrubber.
No preference for item alignment.
Trailing alignment of items within the scrubber.
The scrolling behavior for a scrubber.
A scrolling mode in which scrubber items remain fixed in place, and the item under the user’s finger is highlighted.
A scrolling mode in which the scrubber scrolls as the user swipes horizontally across the scrubber.
The color displayed behind the scrubber content.
A view that is displayed behind the scrubber content.
The object that provides the data for the scrubber.
The object that acts as the delegate of the scrubber.
A Boolean value that determines the behavior of the item selection decorations as the scrubber’s selection changes.
The index of the highlighted item in the scrubber.
Initializes and returns a newly allocated scrubber object from a storyboard or nib file.
Initializes and returns a newly allocated scrubber object with the specified frame rectangle.
Inserts new items at the specified indexes into the scrubber.
A Boolean value that, together with the
property, determines scrubber interaction style.
A setting that specifies the snapping behavior of items in the scrubber.
Returns the view for the item at the specified index.
Creates or returns a reusable item object with the specified identifier.
A setting that determines whether interaction with the scrubber is fixed or free.
Moves an item from one index to another in the scrubber.
The number of items represented by the scrubber.
Combines multiple scrubber content updates into a single action.
Registers a class for the scrubber to use when it creates new items.
Registers a nib file for the scrubber to use when it creates new items in the scrubber.
Reloads the content of the entire scrubber, and deselects the currently selected item.
Reloads the items at the specified indexes.
Removes the items at the specified indexes from the scrubber.
Scrolls an item to a specified alignment within the scrubber.
An object used to describe the layout of items within the scrubber.
The index of the selected item in the scrubber.
The style applied to the background of selected items.
The style overlaid on selected items.
A Boolean value that specifies whether the scrubber should display the existence of additional items beyond the leading and trailing edges.
A Boolean value that specifies whether arrow buttons should be displayed at the leading and trailing edges of the scrubber.
A set of methods that a scrubber data source object implements to provide items to the scrubber from an associated data collection in your app.
Asks the data source object for the view the corresponds to the specified item in the scrubber.
A set of methods that a scrubber delegate implements to respond to user interactions.
Tells the delegate that the user is panning or scrolling the scrubber.
Tells the delegate that a user interaction with the scrubber has been canceled.
Tells the delegate that the item at the specified index was selected.
A concrete layout object that arranges items end-to-end in a linear strip.
A concrete view subclass for displaying images in a scrubber items.
The alignment of the image within the scrubber item.
The image view that the scrubber item uses to display its image.
An item at a specific index position in the scrubber.
An abstract class that describes the layout of items within a scrubber control.
Signals that the layout has been invalidated, and that the scrubber control should perform a new layout pass.
The layout attributes for the item with the specified index.
The set of layout attributes for all items within the provided rectangle.
Gives you an opportunity to perform layout calculations when the scrubber’s layout is invalidated.
The size required to contain all elements within the scrubber.
Determines whether the scrubber should refresh its layout in response to a change of its visible region.
Determines whether the scrubber should refresh its layout when an item is highlighted.
Determines whether the scrubber should refresh its layout when the selection changes.
The layout of a scrubber item.
The item’s alpha value.
The frame of the scrubber item.
The index of the scrubber item that is represented by the item’s layout attributes.
A concrete layout object that sizes each item to some fraction of the scrubber’s visible size.
A concrete view subclass for displaying text for an item in a scrubber.
The text field that the scrubber item uses to display its text.
Methods that responder subclasses implement to support key binding commands, such as inserting tabs and newlines, or moving the insertion point.
An object that provides dynamic contextual controls in the Touch Bar of supported models of MacBook Pro.
A UI control shown in the Touch Bar on supported models of MacBook Pro.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A protocol that marks classes to restore the state of your app to continue a user activity.
A set of methods used to associate a unique identifier with objects in your user interface.
The infrastructure for drawing, printing, and handling events in an app.
A controller that manages a view, typically loaded from a nib file.
Adopt Touch Bar support by displaying interactive content and controls for your macOS apps.

abstract.text: Provide users quick access to your app’s features from a toolbar and corresponding Touch Bar.

abstract.text: A false value.
A true value.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
